Proverbs

Do you want to learn Proverbs in English?

What are Proverbs ?

A proverb is a short sentence that people often quote, which gives advice or tells you something about life. An English proverb is a short, pithy statement that usually offers life advice, wisdom, or a truth. Proverbs are so common that native speakers of English may use them in conversation without realizing it !!


Some commonly used Proverbs:


1. "Actions speak louder than words."
Meaning: What you do is more important than what you say
Example: She promised to help me, but her actions spoke louder than words when she didn't show up.

2. "All good things must come to an end."
Meaning: Everything ends; good times don’t last forever
Example: I wish this vacation would go on forever. It’s too bad that all good things must come to an end.

3. "A stitch in time saves nine."
Meaning: It's better to address a problem early on before it becomes more difficult to fix.
Example: I noticed a small crack in the window and decided to fix it immediately. A stitch in time saves nine.

4. "Don't count your chickens before they hatch."
Meaning:Don't assume you will be successful until you have achieved it.
Example:He was already planning his victory celebration before the game started. His coach reminded him, "Don't count your chickens before they hatch."

5. "Every cloud has a silver lining."
Meaning: Even in difficult situations, there is something positive to be found.
Example:She lost her job, but every cloud has a silver lining. She used the opportunity to start her own business.

6. "The early bird catches the worm."
Meaning: Those who act promptly and decisively have an advantage.
Example: He arrived at the store as soon as it opened and managed to get the last item on sale. The early bird catches the worm.

7. "Practice makes perfect."
Meaning: The more you do something, the better you become at it.
Example: She struggled with playing the piano at first, but with daily practice, she improved. Practice makes perfect.

8. "Don't put all your eggs in one basket."
Meaning: Don't risk everything on a single venture or opportunity.
Example: Instead of investing all his money in a single stock, he diversified his portfolio. He believed in the saying, "Don't put all your eggs in one basket."

9. "When in Rome, do as the Romans do."
Meaning: Adapt to the customs and behavior of the people in a new environment.
Example: Even though she found some local customs strange, she decided to embrace them. After all, when in Rome, do as the Romans do.

10. "Haste makes waste."
Meaning: If you rush and act too quickly, you are likely to make mistakes.
Example: He was in a hurry to finish the project and ended up making several errors. Haste makes waste.

11. "Don't bite the hand that feeds you."
Meaning: Don't harm or be ungrateful towards those who support or provide for you.
Example: He was rude to his boss, forgetting that he depended on him for his livelihood. Don't bite the hand that feeds you.

12. "The pen is mightier than the sword."
Meaning: The power of words and communication is stronger than physical force.
Example: The journalist's article exposed corruption in the government. It showed that the pen is mightier than the sword.

13. "Where there's smoke, there's fire."
Meaning: If there are indications or rumors of a problem, there is likely some truth to it.
Example: People started speculating about the company's financial troubles, and soon after, layoffs were announced. Where there's smoke, there's fire.

14. "Better late than never."
Meaning: It's better to do something late than to not do it at all.
Example: He finally apologized for his mistake a week later. Well, better late than never.

15. "Don't judge a book by its cover."
Meaning: Do not form opinions based solely on appearances.
Example: She appeared shy and reserved, but once you got to know her, you realized she was quite outgoing. Don't judge a book by its cover.

16. "Two wrongs don't make a right."
Meaning: It's not justified to respond to a wrong action with another wrong action.
Example: He was angry because his friend lied to him, but he knew that two wrongs don't make a right, so he chose not to retaliate.

17. "You can't have your cake and eat it too."
Meaning: You can't have or enjoy two conflicting things at the same time.
Example: He wanted to spend all his money on traveling and also save for a house. You can't have your cake and eat it too.

18. "Birds of a feather flock together."
Meaning: People with similar interests, ideas, or characteristics tend to associate with one another.
Example: The students who loved reading often spent time in the library together. Birds of a feather flock together.

19. "The grass is always greener on the other side."
Meaning: People tend to think others' situations are better than their own.
Example: She envied her friend's job until she realized that the grass is always greener on the other side.

20. "All that glitters is not gold."
Meaning: Things that appear attractive or valuable may not be as good as they seem.
Example: The car looked shiny and luxurious, but it had many mechanical issues. All that glitters is not gold.

21. "Fortune favors the bold."
Meaning: Those who take risks and are courageous are more likely to be successful.
Example: He decided to start his own business instead of sticking to a safe job. Fortune favors the bold.

22. "Rome wasn't built in a day."
Meaning: Great things take time to achieve; patience and persistence are necessary.
Example: Learning a new language requires consistent effort and practice. Rome wasn't built in a day.

23. "Curiosity killed the cat."
Meaning: Being too inquisitive or nosy can have negative consequences.
Example: He always pokes around in other people's business. Well, curiosity killed the cat.

24. "The early bird gets the worm."
Meaning: Those who act promptly and arrive early have an advantage.
Example: He woke up at dawn to study for the exam. The early bird gets the worm.

25. "A watched pot never boils."
Meaning: Time seems to move slower when you're eagerly waiting for something.
Example: She kept checking the oven while waiting for the cake to bake. A watched pot never boils.

26. "When the going gets tough, the tough get going."
Meaning: In difficult situations, strong and determined individuals take action.
Example: Despite facing numerous setbacks, she didn't give up and worked harder. When the going gets tough, the tough get going.

27. "Out of sight, out of mind."
Meaning: People tend to forget about things or people that are no longer visible or present.
Example: They used to be close friends, but after moving to different cities, they drifted apart. Out of sight, out of mind.

28. All's fair in love and war."
Meaning: In certain situations, there are no rules or limits to what can be done.
Example: During the game, both teams played aggressively. Well, all's fair in love and war.

29. "Make hay while the sun shines."
Meaning: Take advantage of favorable circumstances while you can.
Example: The weather was perfect for outdoor activities, so they decided to go hiking. Make hay while the sun shines.

30. "A leopard can't change its spots."
Meaning: People cannot change their fundamental nature or character.
Example: Despite promising to change, he continued to engage in dishonest activities. Well, a leopard can't change its spots.

31. "A picture is worth a thousand words."
Meaning: Visual images can convey complex ideas more effectively than written or spoken descriptions.
Example: The photograph of the sunset captured the beauty of the moment—a picture is worth a thousand words.

32. "When in doubt, do without."
Meaning: If unsure about something, it's better to go without it to avoid potential problems or regrets.
Example: She wasn't sure if she should buy the expensive dress. Following the proverb, when in doubt, do without, she decided not to make the purchase.

33. "Two heads are better than one."
Meaning: Collaboration and multiple perspectives lead to better outcomes than working alone.
Example: They worked together on the project and came up with innovative solutions. Two heads are better than one.

34. "The early bird catches the worm, but the second mouse gets the cheese."
Meaning: It's important to strike a balance between being proactive and being cautious.
Example: He decided to observe the situation before taking action. Well, the early bird catches the worm, but the second mouse gets the cheese.

35. "Honesty is the best policy."
Meaning: It's better to be truthful and honest rather than resorting to lies or deceit.
Example: He admitted his mistake and apologized. Honesty is the best policy.

37. "When life gives you lemons, make lemonade."
Meaning: Make the best out of difficult or challenging situations.
Example: Despite facing setbacks, she started her own business. When life gives you lemons, make lemonade.

38. "The more, the merrier."
Meaning: The larger the group or number of people, the more enjoyable or festive the occasion.
Example: She invited all her friends to the party because, in her opinion, the more, the merrier.

39. "The squeaky wheel gets the grease."
Meaning: Those who speak up or make their needs known are more likely to receive attention or assistance.
Example: She voiced her concerns about the project, and her issues were promptly addressed. The squeaky wheel gets the grease.

40. "Where there is a will, there is a way."
Meaning:If someone is determined enough, they will find a solution to a problem or achieve their goals.
Example: Despite facing obstacles, she never gave up and eventually succeeded. Where there is a will, there is a way.

41. "A rolling stone gathers no moss."
Meaning:Constantly changing or moving prevents stagnation or the accumulation of negative influences.
Example: He switched jobs frequently, always seeking new challenges. A rolling stone gathers no moss.

42. "Don't judge a man until you have walked a mile in his shoes."
Meaning:Do not criticize or form opinions about someone until you understand their experiences or perspective.
Example: She didn't understand his behavior until she faced a similar situation. Don't judge a man until you have walked a mile in his shoes.

43. "It's never too late to mend."
Meaning:It is always possible to fix or improve a situation, no matter how late or difficult it may seem.
Example: They hadn't spoken for years, but they reconciled and realized it's never too late to mend.

44. "It's never too late to mend."
Meaning:It is always possible to fix or improve a situation, no matter how late or difficult it may seem.
Example: They hadn't spoken for years, but they reconciled and realized it's never too late to mend.

45. "Better safe than sorry."
Meaning:It's better to be cautious and avoid potential problems or regrets.
Example: He decided to bring an umbrella even though the weather seemed fine. Better safe than sorry.

46. "A watched pot never boils."
Meaning: Time seems to move slower when you are eagerly waiting for something.
Example: He kept checking his email for a response, but a watched pot never boils.

47. "You reap what you sow."
Meaning: Your actions and choices have consequences, and you will experience the results of your own deeds.
Example: He had worked hard and prepared well for the exam, so he achieved good grades. You reap what you sow.

48. "Where there's smoke, there's fire."
Meaning:If there are signs or indications of a problem, there is likely a real issue.
Example: People have been complaining about their service for months. Where there's smoke, there's fire.

49. "A penny saved is a penny earned."
Meaning:Saving money is just as valuable as earning it.
Example: She decided to cut back on unnecessary expenses to save more. A penny saved is a penny earned.

50. "Out of sight, out of mind."
Meaning:People tend to forget about things or people that are no longer visible or present.
Example:They used to be close friends, but after moving to different cities, they drifted apart. Out of sight, out of mind.
